Key Match Events: Eduard Spertsyan scores the fourth goal of the game in favor of Armenia thanks to a right-footed shot that could not be contained by the opposing goalkeeper.
Substitution, Armenia. Grant-Leon Ranos replaces Lucas Zelarayán.
Substitution, Latvia. Renars Varslavans replaces Janis Ikaunieks because of an injury.
Substitution, Armenia. Sergey Muradyan replaces André Calisir because of an injury.
Substitution, Armenia. Zhirayr Shaghoyan replaces Artur Serobyan.
Substitution, Armenia. Edgar Sevikyan replaces Vahan Bichakhchyan.
Substitution, Latvia. Roberts Savalnieks replaces Alvis Jaunzems.
Substitution, Latvia. Vladislavs Gutkovskis replaces Eduards Daskevics.
Substitution, Latvia. Daniels Balodis replaces Kaspars Dubra.
Substitution, Latvia. Dmitrijs Zelenkovs replaces Lukass Vapne.
Yellow card for Janis Ikaunieks in Latvia.
Yellow card for Lukass Vapne in Latvia.
Georgi Harutyunyan scores an own goal and Latvia manages to tie the game unexpectedly.
Vahan Bichakhchyan opens the account for Armenia, after a powerful left-footed shot impossible for the visiting goalkeeper to save.
Kaspars Dubra scores an own goal and Armenia now takes control of the scoreboard with a one-goal difference.
Lucas Zelarayán shot a right-footed shot very close to the visitors' goal to score Armenia's third of the match.
Pre-Game Insights: The home team, ranked 97th in the FIFA ranking, is in a bad moment of form with only 1 win in their last 10 matches between official and friendly matches. What could definitely help them will be the home factor, as in their last 6 home matches they have managed to win or draw in 4 of them, including the 1-1 draw against Wales.

On the away side, we find the 137th in the world also in a not too positive form but with the precedent of almost a year ago when they won at home the Armenian team by 2-0 in a duel that is remembered of a lot of action where the accuracy in front of goal was key. However, as visitors they will have a big problem, having lost 6 of their last 7 away games.

Latvia's best player is Kristers Tobers is a Latvian footballer who plays as a defensive midfielder or central defender. Born on December 13, 2000, Tobers has been a prominent figure in the Latvian national team, known for his defensive solidity, ability to intercept balls and his versatility on the field. He began his career with FK Liepāja, one of Latvia's top clubs, before moving to Lechia Gdańsk in Poland, where he has continued to develop his skills. Tobers is considered one of the most promising young talents in Latvian soccer, with a bright future both for his national team and at club level.

Eduard Spertsyan is an Armenian footballer who has gained recognition as one of the most promising talents of the Armenian national team. Born on June 7, 2000 in Krasnodar, Russia, he plays as an attacking midfielder and is known for his technique, dribbling ability and ability to create attacking moves. Since his debut with FC Krasnodar in the Russian Premier League, he has proven to be a key player for both his club and the Armenian national team. Spertsyan has scored important goals and has been a key player in Armenia's bid to improve its performance in international competitions.
Post-Match Reflections: Armenia defeated Latvia 4-1 to take all three points in their quest to win the group.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match was played at the Republican Stadium Vazgen Sargsyan in Yerevan, Armenia.
The match will be broadcasted on Disney+.
The ball possession was Armenia 66%, Latvia 34%.
